message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emphatic Interpretations of Object Marking in Bantu Languages
Paper Abstract: This paper investigates emphatic interpretations of object marking in various Bantu languages. We focus on Lubukusu (spoken in Kenya) and Cinyungwe (spoken in Mozambique) in particular, but we also report initial evidence from other Bantu languages (mainly Tiriki, Wanga, and Ikalanga). In these languages, OM-doubling—the co-occurrence of an object marker with a lexical DP object—is infelicitous in neutral pragmatic contexts. However, we show that certain contexts make OM-doubling possible. In these contexts, OM-doubling constructions receive particular emphatic interpretations that are very different from interpretations of non-doubling object marking constructions. We identify at least four types of these interpretations: verum, mirativity, exhaustivity, and intensity. We show that emphatic interpretations of OM-doubling are widespread among Bantu languages, and we provide strategies for identifying and analyzing them. While this paper is primarily descriptive, we discuss a possible analysis of these interpretations as conventional implicatures, influenced by recent work on a similar range of emphatic interpretations arising from focus fronting in Indo-European languages.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Focus fronting linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Focus (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Information structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_structure"},{"title":"Topic and comment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic_and_comment"},{"title":"Fronting (sound change) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fronting_(sound_change)"},{"title":"Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistics"},{"title":"Usage-based models of language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usage-based_linguistics"},{"title":"Th-fronting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th-fronting"},{"title":"Prosody (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosody_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Fronting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fronting"},{"title":"Forensic linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forensic_linguistics"}]

Based on the search results, I can provide information about focus fronting in linguistics:

In linguistics, focus is a grammatical category that conveys the part of the sentence that contributes new, non-derivable, or contrastive information.

## What is Fronting Related to Focus?

In syntax, focus can be highlighted by preposing, which is a type of word order change where a focused element is moved to the front of the sentence. Focus can be marked via word order and a nuclear pitch accent.

## Examples

In the English sentence "Mary only insulted BILL", focus is expressed prosodically by a pitch accent on "Bill", which identifies him as the only person whom Mary insulted. By contrast, in the sentence "Mary only INSULTED Bill", the verb "insult" is focused and thus expresses that Mary performed no other actions towards Bill.

## Multiple Ways to Express Focus

Focus may be highlighted either prosodically or syntactically or both, depending on the language.(no content)Cross-linguistically, word order variation (the so-called "inverted sentences") is one of the main syntactic devices used to convey specific information structure configurations, namely the presentational focus.

The search results suggest that focus fronting refers to the syntactic movement of a focused element to the beginning of a clause as a way to mark and emphasize the information that is new or contrastive in a sentence.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Object marking linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Differential object marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_object_marking"},{"title":"Differential argument marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_argument_marking"},{"title":"Object (grammar) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Marker (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marker_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Markedness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markedness"},{"title":"Topic marker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic_marker"},{"title":"Nominative–accusative alignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominative–accusative_alignment"},{"title":"Object–subject–verb word order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-subject-verb"},{"title":"Subject–object–verb word order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject–object–verb_word_order"},{"title":"Marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marking"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about object marking in linguistics:

## Overview

In linguistics, differential object marking (DOM) is the phenomenon in which certain objects of verbs are marked to reflect various syntactic and semantic factors.(no content)DOM is present in more than 300 languages.

## What is a Marker?

A marker is a free or bound morpheme that indicates the grammatical function of the marked word, phrase, or sentence.(no content)Most characteristically, markers occur as clitics or inflectional affixes.

## How Object Marking Works

In languages that have case systems, objects are marked by certain cases (accusative, dative, genitive, instrumental, etc.).(no content)A common basis for differentially marking direct objects is the notion of "prominence," which reflects two properties: definiteness (personal pronoun > proper name > definite NP > indefinite specific NP > non-specific NP) and animacy.(no content)Typically, direct objects that are more prominent are more likely to be overtly case-marked.

## Examples of Languages with Object Marking

Examples of languages with differential object marking are Persian, Turkish, Copala Triqui, Khasi, Tamil, Malayalam, Hindi, Marathi, Kham, Hebrew and Amharic.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about object marking in linguistics:

## Overview

In linguistics, differential object marking (DOM) is the phenomenon in which certain objects of verbs are marked to reflect various syntactic and semantic factors.(no content)DOM is present in more than 300 languages.

## What is a Marker?

A marker is a free or bound morpheme that indicates the grammatical function of the marked word, phrase, or sentence.(no content)Most characteristically, markers occur as clitics or inflectional affixes.

## How Object Marking Works

In languages that have case systems, objects are marked by certain cases (accusative, dative, genitive, instrumental, etc.).(no content)A common basis for differentially marking direct objects is the notion of "prominence," which reflects two properties: definiteness (personal pronoun > proper name > definite NP > indefinite specific NP > non-specific NP) and animacy.(no content)Typically, direct objects that are more prominent are more likely to be overtly case-marked.

## Examples of Languages with Object Marking

Examples of languages with differential object marking are Persian, Turkish, Copala Triqui, Khasi, Tamil, Malayalam, Hindi, Marathi, Kham, Hebrew and Amharic.

Links: [{"title":"Implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicature"},{"title":"Paul Grice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Grice"},{"title":"Scalar implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalar_implicature"},{"title":"Linguistic entailment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entailment_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Talk:Implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Implicature"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Strict conditional - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strict_conditional"},{"title":"Presupposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presupposition"},{"title":"Explicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicature"},{"title":"Truth-conditional semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth-conditional_semantics"}]

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about conventional implicature semantics:

## Overview

In pragmatics, a subdiscipline of linguistics, an implicature is something the speaker suggests or implies with an utterance, even though it is not literally expressed.(no content)The philosopher H. P. Grice coined the term in 1975, distinguishing conversational implicatures, which arise because speakers are expected to respect general rules of conversation, and conventional ones, which are tied to certain words such as but or therefore.

## Key Characteristics

What a speaker conventionally implicates by uttering a sentence is tied in some way to the timeless meaning of part of the sentence, whereas what a speaker conversationally implicates is not directly connected with timeless meaning. This is a fundamental distinction between the two types.

## Examples

An example of a conventional implicature is "Donovan is poor but happy", where the word but implicates a sense of contrast between being poor and being happy. More specifically, in uttering the sentence 'She was poor but she was honest', we say merely that she was poor and she was honest, but we implicate that poverty contrasts with honesty (or that her poverty contrasts with her honesty).

## Further Development

Grice did not elaborate much on the notion of conventional implicature, but many other authors have tried to give more extensive theories of it, including Lauri Karttunen and Stanley Peters, Kent Bach, Stephen Neale, and Christopher Potts.

I've found information about the Lubukusu language in Kenya. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Bukusu is a dialect of the Masaba language spoken by the Bukusu tribe of the Luhya people of western Kenya.(no content)Lubukusu is one of the related but distinct languages that linguists usually treat as separate from other Luhya languages like Lulogooli, Lunyore, and others.

## Relationship to Other Languages

Bukusu is more closely related to the Gisu dialect of Masaaba in eastern Uganda (and to the other Luhya dialect of Tachoni) than it is to other languages spoken by the Luhya.(no content)The Gisu dialect in eastern Uganda is mutually intelligible with Bukusu, spoken by ethnic Luhya in western Kenya.

## Geographic Distribution

The Bukusu tribe lives in Bungoma district, which borders Uganda to the west and Kakamega district of Kenya to the east.(no content)The dialect has regional variations, with distinct forms spoken north of Kimilili, west of Webuye town, and east of Webuye town extending into Kakamega and Lugari districts.

## Language Characteristics

The Bukusu language spoken in Kitale area has largely retained its original form, save for a number of loan words from the nilotic Kalenjin languages of the Pokot, Nandi and Sebei.

Here's a comprehensive overview of Bantu languages based on the search results:

## Overview

The total number of Bantu speakers is estimated to be around 350 million in 2015 (roughly 30% of the population of Africa or 5% of the world population).(no content)Depending on the definition of "language" or "dialect", it is estimated that there are between 440 and 680 distinct languages.

## Geographic Distribution

Bantu languages are largely spoken southeast of Cameroon, and throughout Central, Southern, Eastern, and Southeast Africa.

## Major Bantu Languages

Major Bantu languages include Lingala with more than 20 million speakers (Congo, DRC), followed by Zulu with 13.56 million speakers (South Africa), Xhosa, with 8.2 million speakers (South Africa and Zimbabwe), and Shona with less than 10 million speakers.

## Etymology and Terminology

The technical term Bantu, meaning "human beings" or simply "people", was first used by Wilhelm Bleek. A common characteristic of Bantu languages is that they use words such as muntu or mutu for "human being" or in simplistic terms "person", and the plural prefix for human nouns starting with mu- (class 1) in most languages is ba- (class 2), thus giving bantu for "people".

## Historical Origins

The Bantu languages descend from a common Proto-Bantu language, which is believed to have been spoken in what is now Cameroon in Central Africa. An estimated 2,500–3,000 years ago (1000 BC to 500 BC), speakers of the Proto-Bantu language began a series of migrations eastward and southward, carrying agriculture with them.

A common characteristic of Bantu languages is that they use words such as muntu or mutu for "human being" or in simplistic terms "person", and the plural prefix for human nouns starting with mu- (class 1) in most languages is ba- (class 2), thus giving bantu for "people".

## Historical Origins

The Bantu languages descend from a common Proto-Bantu language, which is believed to have been spoken in what is now Cameroon in Central Africa. An estimated 2,500–3,000 years ago (1000 BC to 500 BC), speakers of the Proto-Bantu language began a series of migrations eastward and southward, carrying agriculture with them.

## Overview

The total number of Bantu speakers is estimated to be around 350 million in 2015 (roughly 30% of the population of Africa or 5% of the world population).(no content)Depending on the definition of "language" or "dialect", it is estimated that there are between 440 and 680 distinct languages.

## Geographic Distribution

Bantu languages are largely spoken southeast of Cameroon, and throughout Central, Southern, Eastern, and Southeast Africa.

## Major Bantu Languages

Major Bantu languages include Lingala with more than 20 million speakers (Congo, DRC), followed by Zulu with 13.56 million speakers (South Africa), Xhosa, with 8.2 million speakers (South Africa and Zimbabwe), and Shona with less than 10 million speakers.

## Etymology and Terminology

The technical term Bantu, meaning "human beings" or simply "people", was first used by Wilhelm Bleek. A common characteristic of Bantu languages is that they use words such as muntu or mutu for "human being" or in simplistic terms "person", and the plural prefix for human nouns starting with mu- (class 1) in most languages is ba- (class 2), thus giving bantu for "people".

## Historical Origins

The Bantu languages descend from a common Proto-Bantu language, which is believed to have been spoken in what is now Cameroon in Central Africa. An estimated 2,500–3,000 years ago (1000 BC to 500 BC), speakers of the Proto-Bantu language began a series of migrations eastward and southward, carrying agriculture with them.

Mey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_L._Mey"},{"title":"Common ground (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_ground_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Jef Verschueren - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jef_Verschueren"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of pragmatics in linguistics:

## Definition

In linguistics and the philosophy of language, pragmatics is the study of how context contributes to meaning.(no content)The field of study evaluates how human language is utilized in social interactions, as well as the relationship between the interpreter and the interpreted.

## Key Distinction from Other Fields

Semantics and pragmatics are branches of linguistics concerned with meaning. These subfields have traditionally been divided according to aspects of meaning: "semantics" refers to grammatical and lexical meanings, while "pragmatics" is concerned with meaning in context.

## Main Areas of Study

Pragmatics focuses on phenomena such as speech acts, implicature, and talk in interaction. More specifically:

- **Implicature and inference:** H. Paul Grice advanced the study of pragmatics in the late 1960s and 1970s by explaining how people mean more than they literally say. Grice's theory of conversational implicature proposed that speakers and hearers are guided by a cooperative principle and a set of rational conversational maxims (e.g. be truthful, be relevant, be brief, be clear). By adhering to or deliberately flouting these maxims, speakers can imply additional meanings which listeners infer in context.

- **Speech acts:** Speech acts, illocutionary force, and interactional norms – the study of how utterances perform actions (asserting, questioning, promising, requesting, apologizing, etc.

## Historical Development

In the 1970s, pragmatics began to gain broader recognition among linguists as a necessary complement to syntax and semantics.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel analytical strategies and frameworks)

**Extracted Triples (7 entities):**

1. **Bantu languages** - Concept (uses) - The primary subject of linguistic investigation
2. **Differential object marking** - Concept (uses) - The core phenomenon being analyzed
3. **Focus (linguistics)** - Concept (uses) - Reference point for similar emphatic phenomena in Indo-European languages
4. **Implicature** - Concept (uses) - Theoretical framework for understanding emphatic interpretations
5. **Bukusu dialect** - Concept (uses) - Lubukusu, one of the primary study languages
6. **Nyungwe language** - Concept (uses) - Cinyungwe, one of the primary study languages
7. **Pragmatics** - Concept (proposes) - Novel analytical strategies for emphatic interpretations as pragmatic phenomena

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms:
- ✅ Paper type correctly set as "contribution"

- ✅ All required fields present and correctly formatted
